content: I've created an issue in rust-lang/libs-team for coming up with a team charter that helps us bootstrap any docs and processes we want going forward: https://github.com/rust-lang/libs-team/issues/1
As a starting point, I've just dropped a few loosely organized topics into a GitHub project we can throw items into and then sift through to figure out what matters to us as a team
Any input of any kind would be awesome! :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:
After the meeting I was thinking of an idea that would make stabilisation more "structured". I can try writing into a proposal of sorts
@DPC that sounds great! If you had any ideas would you like to open an issue on libs-team?
sure I'll do that
I'm going to do an audit of all our unstable tracking issues and RFCs and drop them somewhere in here: https://github.com/rust-lang/libs-team/projects/2
This might take a hot minute..........
As I've been going through I've been adding some labels to issues and dropping nominated on some that seem like we could reasonably kick off a FCP
I've re-organized the tracking project into broad feature groups with RFCs and issues together: https://github.com/rust-lang/libs-team/projects/2
Maybe we can use this to try come up with some project groups to help own some of these columns?
Also anybody feel free to shift things around!
(This looks amazing, thank you for spending the time!)
We also have some pre-existing automation, currently used for core team's similar board, that automatically puts issues on the board and moves them depending on the label tagged
maybe worth considering for this
If you think that'd be helpful I can spend some cycles getting it setup
Automation sounds amazing! :+1: I wanted to do it all manually as a first pass just as an excuse to visit all the issues and feel the pain to automate :smile:
Well, we'd need the first pass regardless to get everything sorted, but I'll take a look at hooking up some automation soon then!
That will be so great :bow: I’m hoping we can do a few passes over the board to get it organised the way we like and can start working through some of these long-term unstable features
@Ashley Mannix Oh, there is so many issues in the libs-tracked did you add them one by one?
I did yeh :laughing: That's all our open RFCs and _most_ of our tracking issues. There's still a fair chunk to pull in that haven't been updated in the last few months
I’ve now got all our open tracking issues on the board (there’s still some organizing to do for the incoming column)

I've started sketching out something of an RFC for Libs governance. It's just rough notes right now but wanted to put it forward sooner rather than later to see whether you all think it's going in the right direction: https://hackmd.io/FasfT5zzQZuy0c0AxYQRBg

This looks great so far. :big_smile: Something I would like to see added to the triage is some kind time limit on an unstable feature if it’s doesn’t have a clear path. For example; if there’s no meaningful activity in 18 months.

I think we often run into a problem of putting off work with the intent of getting to it next week, only to repeat that. (To be clear; I’m not innocent of this either) So having some kind of hard limit would help keep that under control.
That sounds like a good idea :+1:
generally not keen on having a "concrete time-bound" since it could vary depending on features, and some might just take longer for stabilisation. better to take it on a case-by-case approach

@DPC That’s fair. Some features are tiny and some are ongoing. I think this would be more as a way to age out unstable features that don’t have any clear path to stabilization, and don’t have anybody interested in pushing them forward

Taking it on a case by case is what we have been doing, and I don’t think it works. There are plenty of features that take years, but any feature that sits without active work on it for a year and half is going to need to be rethought to fit in the current context, and at that point keeping around open issues only hurts not helps that effort.

To give a specific example, I don’t think anyone could give a clear path to stabilisation forconcat_idents!, and there doesn’t seem to be interest in that for the current version. It would be more beneficial to close and deprecate, and let interest in a new iteration come organically from a new proposal, rather than keeping it in a long todo list.
Hi Ashley, I have made an adjustment to the start of the doc. I would like the emphasis to be around the team and building the community's trust.
That’s awesome, thanks! Please feel free to add/change anything you see fit 👍
@Ashley Mannix on that note should we create a @t-libs/meta channel on the same lines as compiler & lang team does, since it becomes easier to brainstorm a few ideas on how we carry this forward
@DPC Do you know who we talk to about getting new streams created?
@simulacrum should be able to
yep I can do that for y'all
https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/253831-t-libs.2Fwg-meta
Thanks @simulacrum!
@simulacrum Minor nit: The channel is called wg-meta but there's no meta libs working group. Should it be just meta?
That's a fair point. The same would go for t-lang/wg-meta; perhaps that should just be t-lang/meta?
renamed t-libs/meta
@Josh Triplett Well there originally was a language meta working group in early 2019. The effort was merged with the governance working group but the stream has stuck around since.

gonna reuse this topic I guess
@Josh Triplett @Mara are y'all okay with cancelling the libs team charter meeting this wednesday after the API meeting?
I just had to schedule a meeting in the same time slot to talk about the issue you brought up regarding the foundation @Mara
sure!
:+1:
I'm working on polishing up the libs charter rn and I'm wondering, do we have an email alias for the team?
need to figure out what to put as the point of contact for the libs team
I believe there's a mailing list for libs; I don't know if there's also one for libs-api.
ill need a contact for each team
so we should setup a mailing list for api I expect
But IIRC, "point of contact" was intended to be a single person, typically the lead. We can list a preferred list as well, but the goal was to have one person to list for each team.

Jane Lusby said:

so we should setup a mailing list for api I expect

We may have one already, I just don't know.
hmm
ill leave that for now then
There should be a mailing list for libs-api.
libs-api@rust-lang.org
It's in the teams repository.
